phrase.item: They say that there was once a poor man and that he had nothing; he had two daughters and one wife.
\ He complained often and cried: I have nothing at all on earth.
One night in a dream he saw the sun on his right shoulder and the moon on his left shoulder.

He said: "Hey wife, prepare a meal." She said: "And what do you have for me to prepare a meal, for me to organize a xhedoyi [ritual meal]. He said: "If you have a lamp, light it; I will find my [walking] stick."
His wife said to him: "There is no lamp here." He got up, found his [walking] stick in the darkness and set off.
He crossed many steppes and deserts and arrived in a place where he became very hungry.
A shephard appeared
He said: "Is this a devil?"
And he said: "I am not going to kill it, it may be a person."
He called him and said: "Hey you, are you a devil or a person?"
That one said: "I am not a devil,"
"I am a person!"
He said: "Where are you going?"
He said: "Hey shepherd, give me a piece of bread!"
What gives you the right to ask me so many questions?
He said: "Tell me about your purpose here, then I will give you some bread."
The poor man said: "You cannot understand my business." He said: "In a dream I saw the sun resting on my one of my shoulders, the moon resting on the other."
"I had this dream and I set off." The shepherd said to him: "Give me your dream, and I will give you my herd." He responded: "Hey shepherd, do not mock me!"
He said: "I will give you my herd." And he gave the man his herd and the man gave him his dream.
The poor man turned back, he arrived at his house that same night.
He began yelling: "Hey wife!"
"Get up, open the door!"
The wife said to her daughters: "Hey, daughters!"
"Get up, open the door!"
They said: "Hey, mother!"
"We are young, you are old, what if some thief were there?"
"Go out yourself!"
She went out and it was the man's voice.
She opened the gate: there was a lot of livestock.
He said: "Hey wife!"

"See how much livestock I found" She said: "Don't go any further, otherwise you will be stealing the livestock from some king and will bring disaster upon us." They realized that they did not have a container to milk the livestock.
He went to find a bowl for milking.
The black night turned to day, he took the container he had milked in to a shopkeeper: "Take this, or I will die of hunger." The shopkeeper kicked it, the milk spilled, and he [the man] began to cry.
He said: "Hey, shopkeeper!"
"My food was in this container and you broke it, now what will I milk my livestock in?"
He said: "If you have livestock, I can spare you this bucket."

"In this bucket you will be able to milk for yourself, and bring the rest to me." He took the bucket; after having milked the milk and with pleasure drunk some himself, he brought [the rest] to the other.
This one gave him some money, and he became very rich, and in this way built himself a castle better than that of a king!
The wishes of the poor man were fulfilled.
[Meanwhile] the shepherd had taken the dream for himself, crossed many steppes and deserts and reached a kingdom.
During the day he worked, and at night he slept at the base of the king's tower.
The king had a daughter and the vizier had a son.
The vizier's son often went to the home of the king's daughter.
One day the vizier's son came, and a servant was sitting [there], the very beautiful one.
The vizier's son said: "Hey servant, where is the princess?"
She said: "How should I know where you are and where your princess is?"
The vizier's son said: "You are so beautiful, yet you are a slave; she is so monstrous, yet she is a princess!"
The slave was offended, went to see the king, and said: "O king!"

"See how the son of the vizier employs his force." She said: "He also impregnated your daughter:" The king said: "In the morning bring my daughter and tie her to a cannon." But an old woman that had raised the king's daughter and been her wet-nurse reported to her: "O princess, tomorrow you and the son of the vizier will be torn apart by a canon." She and the son of the vizier conferred: "This very night, we will escape."
At night, the vizier's son and the princess prepared for the journey.
But the son of the vizier fell into the hands of the watchmen and they threw him into the dungeon.
The princess, when she left, saw no one.
The princess went out onto the tower and saw that someone was sleeping at the foot of the tower.
She said: "It's perhaps the son of the vizier." She descended, caught her horse with a lasso. She approached, shook the shepherd, the shepherd awoke, and he put her in the saddle behind him.
They crossed many steppes and deserts, [and] reached a forest: it was not yet light.
The king's daughter asked: "Hey, son of the vizier!"
"If in this forest you also had a horse, that would be very nice."
The shepherd said: "O princess!"
"If there was livestock here, that would [indeed] be very nice." She said: "Oh!"
"He tricked me, he is actually a shepherd!"
She brandished her dagger: "I will strike him with my dagger."
Next she thought: "It is clear that my fate is linked to his."
"I must go with him." They escaped, and reached another city. [From GSK; Wakhi seems to have more]
The princess advised the shepherd, saying: "Firstly, do not take any companion with you; secondly, tell no one the secret of your heart!"
The shepherd thought: "It appears that this princess is very foolish!"
T"ake no companion with me? If it happens that I fall ill, my companion will send word." He took a companion.
The companion said to him: "Hey shepherd!"
"Either you invite me,"
"or I invite you." He said to his wife: "O princess!"
"Today make a good meal, my companion will come as a guest."
She said: "I told you not to take any companion with you!"
"And you did not do so!"
He said: "Wife, I took a companion!"
He prepared for the guest, brought his companion, [and] placed seven different dishes before him.
That [man] said: "Hey, companion!"
"I did not come here to eat, but to see my sister." He brought his wife, [and] showed her to him.
The companion fainted, then recovered his spirits and left.
He went to tell the king of the city, saying: "A man from some city has arrived here; he has a wife who glows like a lamp."
"She is worthy of you." The king called his two viziers, his right-hand and his left-hand, and said: "O viziers!"
"Let us kill this man, I will take his wife." The vizier on his left said: "Good!"
The vizier on his right said: "O king!"
"You must not kill him."
"It will give you a bad name, and if another king hears of it it will be complete dishonor."
He said: "Vizier, then how will we proceed?"
He said: "Demand that he come tomorrow and take him with you to the forestof Mazəngəron, order him to hunt." The king said: "Who will bring him to me?"
This companion [of the man's] was a royal groom, he said: "I will bring him." He came and said: "Hey, companion!"
"The king will call you before him, [to say:] 'I have given you a task.'" They set off together and approached the king and greeted him.
The king said: "What is your name?"
He said: "My name is Brave Zemtchi." He said: "What bravery do you have?"
He said: "My father and mother gave me my name, I have no other bravery."
He said: "Come tomorrow morning, you will go hunting with me in the forest of Məzəngəron". He said: "Very well," and returned to his home.
The princess asked him: "What gift did the king give to you? Unless he has given you a position?"
He said: "He gave me nothing."
He said, "He told me: 'We will go hunting together in the Məzəngəron forest.'" The princess said: "Idiot!"
"From the beginning I advised you to not take a companion with you, to tell no one the secret of your heart!"
"You did not listen, you took a companion; now you will be taken hunting in the Mazəngəron forest, and it is because of me."
"In the Məzəngəron forest there are lions, tigers; all the creatures and monsters of the world are in the Məzəngəron forest."
Brave Zemtchi became pensive.
The princess said: "Take a steel sword, take my horse Wind."
‎‎"Tomorrow when you go hunting with the king, when you reach the forest of Məzəngəron, say: 'O steel sword!'"
"'O horse Wind!'"
"'You know yourselves!'"
"Place the reins on the saddle bow, then the steel sword and the horse, Wind, will know [what to do]."
"The steel sword will slice, the horse, Wind, will understand--do not get involved!"
In the morning, he went to the king's home; the king had already saddled up his horse.
They set off and once they came near the Məzəngəron forest, the king climbed to the top of a hill and sent him into the Məzəngəron forest.
He approached the Mazəngəron forest and said: "O steel sword!"
"O horse Wind!"
He placed the reins on the seat of the saddle and whipped the horse, Wind.
The horse, Wind, rushed into the Mazəngəron forest--the steel sword sliced and the horse Wind kicked and bit.
He pillaged the Mazəngəron forest, returned to the hill, and approached the king, but the king was very sad and melancholy.
The king then returned to his castle and asked his viziers for advice.
He said: "Viziers!"
"He pillaged the Mazəngəron forest." He said: "What shall we do?"

The vizier to his left said: "Let us kill him." The vizier to his right refused: "It will give us a bad name. They will say that there was in this kingdom a brave man, whose name was Brave Zemtchi, and that he pillaged the Mazəngəron forest... It will be a great dishonor to us."
He [the king] said: "Vizier, what shall I do?"
He said: "Demand that he come before you and send him to Mount Qof to find the mare with forty foals—there forty devils will devour him.” The king said: “Who will bring him?”
The royal groom who was Brave Zemtchi’s companion said: “I will bring him.” And the groom went to find him, [saying:] “The king has said: ‘Come, I will give you a position.’”
They set off again and came to the royal palace.
Once again he greeted the king.
The king said to him: “Go and bring back the mare with forty foals.”
He said: “Very well.” Once again he came to his home. The princess asked him: “What position did the king give you?”
He said: “He did not give me any.”
“He said: ‘Go and bring back the mare with forty foals.’”
She said: "Idiot!"
“The mare with forty foals is on Mount Qof where forty devils will devour you.” He said: “Well, [we must] trust in God.”
The princess said to him: “I will make you provisions for the journey.”
“Wake up at night and set off so that you arrive before the sun rises; when you arrive, just as the sun is rising, the forty devils will be sleeping.”
“When you enter the castle, place the steel sword on the bow of the saddle of the horse Wind.”
“Call out: ‘O forty devils!’ ”
“‘Come outside, a troop has come [to make] war.’”
“Say: ‘O horse Wind!’”
“‘O steel sword!’”
"'You know yourselves!'"
“The horse Wind and the steel sword will attack so well that they will shock the entire world.”
When his wife had explained everything to him, he took the steel sword and left quickly.
He crossed several steppes and deserts

And arrived at the castle of the forty devils[, saying: “O forty devils! A troupe has surrounded you!” They woke up and came out of the palace in an state of confusion.] [Bracketed portion only present in French text.]
He called out: “O horse Wind!”
“O steel sword!”
"You know yourselves!"
The steel sword and the horse Wind attacked so well that they slayed the forty devils.
Brave Zemtchi entered and a fairy was sitting there.
The fairy said: "O brave Zemtchi!"
“Leave or the forty devils will wake up and kill you!”
He said: “I have killed the forty devils.” She said: “Stop lying!”
She went outside where the bodies of the forty devils had fallen.
She said to him: "O brave Zemtchi!"
"Stay with me!"
He said: “I have come here to find the mare with forty foals.” She said: “The mare with forty foals, even the forty devils could not tame—what could you do [with her]?”
He said: "I will go"
The fairy said: “What good is it to go for no reason?”
“I will give you some advice.” He said: “What advice will you give me?”
She said to him: “When you go you will come across the spring of desires.”
She goes there on Fridays to drink water.
“When you get there, take with you a gourd of paj [kefir].”

“Take a silver saddle, reins, and a girth, and when you reach the edge of the spring [dig a pit, hide yourself in it and cover it with branches. Place the saddle and the reins beside the spring.”] [Bracketed portion only present in French text.]

“When the mare with forty foals comes to drink, she will drink some water, lift her head, and see the silver saddle and the reins by the spring’s edge; the mare with forty foals will say: ‘Where is the master who will tame me?’”
Say: "Here I am, I am your master!"

“When you come out, saddle her, and mount her, she will say: ‘Before, the length of my stride was forty meters; now it is seventy meters.’ When you get in the saddle and she begins to buck, hit her head with the gourd of kefir.”
“When the gourd breaks the kefir will spill over her face.”
“She will say: ‘My brain is leaking.’ She will say: ‘O earth man!”

“‘You are shockingly cruel, with one blow you have smashed open my brain.’ You will say: ‘I hit you very lightly, but if you bolt again I will hit you [so hard that] you’ll fall.’” Brave Zemtchi got up and set off, and came to the spring of desires. He duck a ditch, covered it with branches, then got into it and hid.
On Friday the mare with forty foals appeared, drank some water, and lifted her head to see the silver saddle and reins.
She said: "Where is the master who will tame me?"
A voice was heard: “It is I.” She said: “Come out!”
He came out, saddled her, and mounted.
The mare with forty foals said: “Before, the length of my stride was forty meters; now it is seventy meters.” He put his foot in the stirrup and got up.
When she began to buck, he emptied the gourd of kefir behind her ear. The kefir dripped over her face.
She said: “O earth man!”
“You are very cruel, you are unfair!” He said: “How so?”
She said: “With one blow you have smashed open my brain.”
He said: “If you rear up one more time, I will hit you [so hard that] you’ll fall!”
The mare with forty foals became calm and submitted to him.
He took the forty foals by the bridle and led them to the fairy.
He took the fairy and the wealth of the forty devils, loaded them onto the mare with forty foals, and set off.
The mare with forty foals rose into the air and brought him down in the that same kingdom where the daughter of the king was.
The princess said: "So, you've brought it?"
He said: “I brought it, and I brought a fairy too.”
The princess said to him: “Well then, a blessing on you.” She said: “Take the mare with forty foals to the king!”
He took them to the king.
When he reached the king, the king once again became pensive, called for his viziers and asked the viziers, both the left-hand and the right: “What shall we do with him?”
The vizier on the left said: “Kill him.” The vizier on the right said: “No.” And the king said again: “What shall we do?”
The vizier on the right said: “Call him in again, we shall send him to the other world.”
Once again they called him in.
The king said to him: "O Brave Zemtchi!"
“You are [indeed] very brave!”
“Go and bring me word of my mother and father in the other world!”
He said: “Very well.” He returned home.
The princess asked him: "What gift did the king give to you? Unless he has given you a position?”
He said: "He gave me nothing."
“He said to me: ‘Go to the other world and bring word of my mother and father!’”
The princess said: “[And] you’re able to go to the other world?”
He said: “Well, [this is my] fate!”
She said: “Up to now I’ve gotten you out of every disaster, now to go the fairy.”
“If the fairy doesn’t know [what to do], then come back to me.”

He went to the fairy, told the fairy [what had occurred], and the fairy said to him: “Do not go near the king for seven days; after seven days I will tell you how to answer the king.” After seven days she said: “O Brave Zemtchi!”
“When you go to the king, say to the king: ‘I was in the other world with your mother and father.’”

“ ‘They said: “Let him go to the Mazəngəron forest and make a pile of brushwood forty meters high and forty meters wide.” Your parents also said: “Let him [the king] climb on top with the left-hand vizier, and then let you [Zemtchi] and the right-hand vizier strike a match and set it on fire.” ’ ”
“When you set the fire all of a sudden they will not be able to get down from any side, so they will burn on top.”
“So the kingdom will fall to you.” When the fairy had said all this, he went to the king.
The king said: “[So,] you were in the other world?”
He said: "Yes!"
He said: “How are things for my father and mother?”
He said: "Everything is good for your father and mother."
“Your parents said: ‘Let the king order him to the Mazəngəron forest to make a pile of brushwood forty meters high and forty meters wide.’ ”
“ ‘Then let him climb to the top with his left-hand vizier, to see how we are doing.’ ”
The king ordered that the brushwood be gathered from the Mazəngəron forest and the pile be made.
When the pile was made, he measured it [to see that it was] forty meters high and forty meters wide.
‎‎Next he climbed up on top with his left-hand vizier.
The right-hand vizier and Brave Zemtchi struck a match and set [the pile] on fire.
They could no longer get down from any side, and they burned on the top.
The right-hand vizier remained the vizier, and Brave Zemtchi became the king.
He brought the fairy and the princess, sat on the royal throne, and [in this way] attained the throne and good fortune.
